title: Debilsumda
author: Debilsumda
content: Or at least these sites with the whole database from people personal and "secret private keys and mnemonics". All the people who made them are scammers, even ian coleman shouldn't exist in its form. How is private when all people keys, adresses and all are publicly exposed in the freakin open web? No wonder why so many people got scammed and this is utter sh.t. I absolutely mean it while im trying to find my long lost adress before someone else do it. Even if you think a bit more out of the box you can get much more relevant adresses in ian coleman,forget all other databases exposed publicly. Crypto isn't same anymore, just throw an eye on the coleman wsite traffic between 2020 and mid of 2022...all these dorment accounts didn't wake up, they were scammed, by who its obvious. Prove me wrong that holding crypto is secure these days.

comments.author: Helena Yu
comments.body: Crypto aka shitcoins should be banned, Bitcoin must not.Quote from: https://bitcoin.stackexchange.com/questions/92540/bruteforcing-a-seed-with-24-words-of-a-unknown-orderThis depends a little bit if all words are independent. If yes the will be 24! = 620.448.401.733.239.439.360.000 permutations of the words. Assuming that you computer can check 1 billion permutations per second (which is is way too optimistic as this would assume that a signature / public key could be computed within one clock cycle which he can't) this would mean that your computer still would need 620.448.401.733.239 seconds which is 19674289 (19.6 million) years as the absolut minor / lower bound. This estimation however does not take into account technological breakthroughs in computing hardware which could very well happen in that time frame (:

comments.author: pawel7777
comments.body: Nice rant OP, but can you be a bit clearer on what you mean specifically? Have you fallen a victim to the fake Ian Coleman Bip 39 generator scam, discussed here: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5425314.0Bitcoin is and never was a safe space. If you don't like the risk just stick to regulated centralised exchanges with client deposits insurance (they won't be insured with FDIC or FSCS though afaik).And yes, we've been hearing about the crypto being banned "soon" since the beginning. Still waiting...

comments.author: LoyceMobile
comments.body: Quote from: Debilsumda on January 14, 2023, 01:49:25 PMeven ian coleman shouldn't exist in its form.You've managed to post an amazing amount of BS in just a day. None of it even deserves a response.

Assuming that you computer can check 1 billion permutations per second (which is is way too optimistic as this would assume that a signature / public key could be computed within one clock cycle which he can't) this would mean that your computer still would need 620.448.401.733.239 seconds which is 19674289 (19.6 million) years as the absolut minor / lower bound. This estimation however does not take into account technological breakthroughs in computing hardware which could very well happen in that time frame (:But still, you can find everyone privkey in the open web with its balance, overall everything, how's this private way of keeping funds?The second i find me account, will definitely withdrawal all, and make a lawsuit towards every owner of these wsites containing peoples private information. Only if someone didn't scam me before that and we gon read, "another crypto whale woke up or sum bs like this".

comments.author: mindrust
comments.body: Quote from: Helena Yu on January 14, 2023, 01:59:06 PMCrypto aka shitcoins should be banned, Bitcoin must not.Quote from: https://bitcoin.stackexchange.com/questions/92540/bruteforcing-a-seed-with-24-words-of-a-unknown-orderThis depends a little bit if all words are independent. If yes the will be 24! = 620.448.401.733.239.439.360.000 permutations of the words. Assuming that you computer can check 1 billion permutations per second (which is is way too optimistic as this would assume that a signature / public key could be computed within one clock cycle which he can't) this would mean that your computer still would need 620.448.401.733.239 seconds which is 19674289 (19.6 million) years as the absolut minor / lower bound. This estimation however does not take into account technological breakthroughs in computing hardware which could very well happen in that time frame (:Nobody's banning anything. Shitcoins deserve to survive as much as bitcoin. In fact some shitcoins are as good as bitcoin, if not more. They aren't many but there are a few. And once you ban every shitcoin in existence you are also banning the new tech from emerging. Bitcoin don't need that kind of artificial monopoly. Bitcoin is and will always be the best as long as it updates itself with the new tech as it did before with segwit.

comments.author: decodx
comments.body: Quote from: Debilsumda on January 14, 2023, 01:49:25 PM<...>Prove me wrong that holding crypto is secure these days. WTF are you talking about? Can you give an example of a website that has a database containing people's private keys and mnemonics?I could prove you wrong with statistics and data, but why bother? It's obvious that you're unwilling do accept any form of evidence unless it confirms your own biases. I guess it depends on your personal perspective, but if you're looking for complete security, you might as well be looking for a unicorn riding a leprechaun.

comments.author: bittraffic
comments.body: Obviously, he doesn't know much about crypto and blockchain. It's funny that because the ledger is available to the public means there will be lots of users gonna be scammed or hacked. You should know that countries banning BTC will just be left behind when all other countries are heading to digital currency. Eventually, the CBDC may actually allow BTC in their platform. There is no banning that will happen.

There is no banning that will happen.I said it wrong okay i understand, not the crypto should be banned, but all wsites containing all the information from people private keys. Its hard to find an adress information in them, but odds are Â way too big, for them to exist. Like i said, check the wayback machine, and see how much simple site like the ian coleman tool, is used between 2020 and 2022.And you're so fast to judge who knows and who dont, im for crypto to be legal tender since i got involved in it, before even satoshi accepted a coin in return 50+.

comments.author: ilovealtcoins

Assuming that you computer can check 1 billion permutations per second (which is is way too optimistic as this would assume that a signature / public key could be computed within one clock cycle which he can't) this would mean that your computer still would need 620.448.401.733.239 seconds which is 19674289 (19.6 million) years as the absolut minor / lower bound. Bitcoin is and will always be the best as long as it updates itself with the new tech as it did before with segwit.No altcoin can be as good as bitcoin, but there is no reason to ban altcoins. Only people who don't profit from altcoins support banning them, they are just as jealous as the bitcoin haters out there.

comments.body: Listen lads, i dont vouch crypto to be banned. My intentions are against the bunch of wsites and their creators to be held in court and state a hard proof that they didnt touched a single dorment or not dorment adress. You can't tell me that these people didnt steal at least a coin from couple adresses, even coin is little, some im sure stole huge amounts from these aka dorment accounts who suddenly woke up. No matter active or not its not right.Quote from: decodx on January 14, 2023, 02:36:57 PMQuote from: Debilsumda on January 14, 2023, 02:18:35 PMQuote from: decodx on January 14, 2023, 02:10:29 PMWTF are you talking about? comments.author: franky1
comments.created_time: January 14, 2023, 02:47:31 PMLast edit: January 14, 2023, 03:13:57 PM by franky1
comments.body: those websites are not what you thinkread the first linkQuoteHow does this work?A private key is basically just a number between 1 and 2256. This website generates keys for all of those numbers, spread out over pages of 128 keys each.This website doesn't actually have a database of all private keys, that would take an impossible amount of disk space. Instead, keys are procedurally generated on the fly when a page is opened. The page number is used to calculate which keys should be on that page. using math you should be able to work out how many possible private keys there could ever beand to check them all. how much time it would takeits like115,792,089,237,316,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000imagine you tried 1million a second checks115,792,089,237,316,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000seconds to perform1,929,868,153,955,270,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000Â Â Â minute32,164,469,232,587,800,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000Â Â Â hour1,340,186,218,024,490,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000Â Â Â day3,671,743,063,080,800,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000Â Â Â year104,906,944,659,451,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000Â Â Â 35 years26,226,736,164,862,900,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000Â Â Â 4 descendant generationsyep in 140 year there are still26,226,736,164,862,900,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000Â Â Â combinations you have not triedtry to realise how big that number is..trying ONE million combinations every second for 1000 yearsstill leaves you with3,671,743,063,080,800,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,00that you have not triedtrying to find your random number in that number is going to take anyone more then they can imaginethere is soo much entropy/ breadth of possibilities its not simply finding a pin in a haystack its finding a specific grain of carbon that could be on any planet in the universethere are only 43million used addressesmeaning 1 address is randomly somewhere in2,666,340,940,292,410,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000possible private keys

Forget my adress, i will find it this way even tho im vouching against it, its my way to regain it. But nowadays you don't need to be experienced hacker to steal from people.

comments.author: DanWalker
comments.body: Quote from: Helena Yu on January 14, 2023, 01:59:06 PMCrypto aka shitcoins should be banned, Bitcoin must not.Quote from: https://bitcoin.stackexchange.com/questions/92540/bruteforcing-a-seed-with-24-words-of-a-unknown-orderThis depends a little bit if all words are independent. If yes the will be 24! = 620.448.401.733.239.439.360.000 permutations of the words. Assuming that you computer can check 1 billion permutations per second (which is is way too optimistic as this would assume that a signature / public key could be computed within one clock cycle which he can't) this would mean that your computer still would need 620.448.401.733.239 seconds which is 19674289 (19.6 million) years as the absolut minor / lower bound. This estimation however does not take into account technological breakthroughs in computing hardware which could very well happen in that time frame (:This is the crypto market, and if bitcoin is not a cryptocurrency, it shouldn't be at the top of the ratings. Bitcoin is also a cryptocurrency, the best cryptocurrency. Bitcoin would still work without altcoins, but bitcoin's value would never be what it is today. Bitcoin alone cannot create a market, and without altcoins, many people still don't know about bitcoin. If you are here just to use bitcoin as a means of payment, or currency, then you don't need altcoins. But if you are here for profit like others, then altcoins are needed to increase bitcoin prices.

Okay its not the private, but still is enough to give someone a lead, also im sure he's affiliated with one if those sites. It's just not right, yes you can see it in blockchain but its different when someone made a whole list arranged by balance and alphabetically.

comments.author: franky1
comments.body: those websites dont work as you thinkwhat it does is have numbers from 1 to 128 on page 1by you picking a "page number" its simply doing page number *128and displaying the number, and then converting it to a private then a publicthe website is not storing its not checking prior to you deciding on a page numberits just displaying a random number of a page of YOUR choosingconverting it and then checkingthere is no hack there is no storage. its just plain mathyou're trying to find a specific grain of carbon in all the carbon of the universe

comments.author: Debilsumda
comments.created_time: January 14, 2023, 03:27:38 PMLast edit: January 14, 2023, 03:43:09 PM by Debilsumda
comments.body: Quote from: franky1 on January 14, 2023, 03:17:05 PMthose websites dont work as you thinkwhat it does is have numbers from 1 to 128 on page 1by you picking a "page number" its simply doing page number *128and displaying the number, and then converting it to a private then a publicthe website is not storing its not checking prior to you deciding on a page numberits just displaying a random number of a page of YOUR choosingconverting it and then checkingthere is no hack there is no storage. its just plain mathyou're trying to find a specific grain of carbon in all the carbon of the universe On some you can jump on different pages, other scan automatically, yes chance is little, but in this case imagine someone with a whole farm of 100 trash phones scaning constantly, tell me the result is the same like guessing the private key alone? I think little chance in case like this turns to enormous.Also the fact that loyce answer was ad hominem is pure example that it isn't completely like you described it.Also im curious whats the mystery behind the huge traffic on sites like this still will add ian coleman tool, between 2020 and 2022? How come sleeping adresess got drained with huge amounts in the span of couple months?
